Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter who is among the most famous and influential figures in Western art. Born on March 30, 1853, in Groot-Zundert, Netherlands, he was the eighth child of Theodorus van Gogh and Anna Cornelia Carbentus. Van Gogh struggled throughout his life, facing mental health issues and poverty, which impacted his personal relationships and artistic career.

At an early age, Van Gogh pursued a career in ministry but soon found his calling in art. He took drawing classes in The Hague and later in Paris, where he encountered the works of Impressionist and Neo-Impressionist painters, which inspired his unique style. Van Gogh was known for his emotional depth and bold use of color, which later influenced the development of Expressionism.

Van Gogh began his professional art career in 1880, painting en plein air (outdoors) and focusing on landscapes, still life, and scenes of rural life. In 1886, he moved to Arles, France, where he hoped to establish an artists' community. However, his mental health deteriorated, leading to the infamous incident where he cut off part of his left ear.

After this event, Van Gogh spent some time in a psychiatric facility in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence. During this period, he produced some of his best work, including iconic paintings such as "The Starry Night" (1889) and "Sunflowers" (1888). Despite his limited commercial success, Van Gogh was supported by his brother Theo, an art dealer, who sold his paintings and corresponded with him frequently.

Van Gogh died on July 29, 1890, after shooting himself in the chest. He was 37 years old. His body was hastily buried in the Saint-Rémy cemetery. Van Gogh produced over 2,100 artworks, including around 860 oil paintings, and more than 1,300 sketches and watercolors.

Who is Vincent van Gogh?

Vincent van Gogh (1853-1890) was a Dutch post-impressionist painter whose work profoundly influenced 20th-century art. Van Gogh created about 2,100 artworks, including around 860 oil paintings, most of which date from the last two years of his life.

Early life and education

Born on March 30, 1853, in Zundert, Netherlands, van Gogh came from a family of artists. His younger brother Theo, an art dealer, provided Vincent with a steady source of income and emotional support throughout his career. Although Vincent initially pursued a career in art as a minister of religion, he was not successful and, by 1880, had abandoned the idea. Instead, he sought to follow in his family's footsteps and become an artist.

He started his artistic journey in 1880 by enrolling at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Brussels, Belgium, where he studied under the guidance of renowned artist Jean-François Millet. However, Van Gogh's dissatisfaction with the traditional academic style led him to explore more avant-garde techniques and subjects, like Impressionism and Japanese art, which greatly influenced his later work.

Artistic career

After his time at the Royal Academy, van Gogh moved to Paris in 1886, where he became exposed to new artistic styles, such as Impressionism and Neo-Impressionism. There, he befriended artists like Paul Gauguin and Émile Bernard, and his style began to evolve.

From 1888 onwards, van Gogh settled in the South of France, spending two years painting at the asylum of Saint-Rémy. During this period, his artwork became more emotional and expressive, which was a stark contrast to his previous, more realistic depictions. His paintings during this time, including "The Starry Night," "Café Terrace at Night," and "Wheatfield with Cypresses," reflect his fascination with the countryside, and his use of bold, expressive brushstrokes and vibrant colors.

text:
Upton Sinclair


Vincent Willem van Gogh (30 March 1853 – 29 July 1890) was a Dutch post-impressionist painter who is among the most famous and influential figures in the history of Western art. Despite his profound impact on the art world, he lived a life of intense struggle, personal tragedy, and mental illness.


Born in Zundert, Netherlands, van Gogh showed a precocious talent for drawing from an early age. After an unsuccessful stint as an art dealer and a period of working for the art dealers Goupil & Cie, he embraced art as a career. In 1880, van Gogh moved to Paris, where he was influenced by the work of impressionists and began developing his distinctive painting style.


After a brief period in Paris, van Gogh settled in the south of France, where he would produce some of his most celebrated work. In Arles, he painted scenes of the Provençal landscape and the local peasantry, while in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, he created many of his most famous works while staying in an asylum for mental health treatment.


Van Gogh's personal life was marked by turbulence and difficulty. He suffered from mental health issues, including depression and episodes of psychosis, which led to his voluntary admission to a mental institution. Despite his artistic genius, van Gogh lived in poverty and was only modestly successful during his lifetime.


Tragically, on 29 July 1890, at the age of 37, van Gogh's life ended abruptly. He shot himself in the chest at a wheat field near Auvers-sur-Oise, France. His death did not draw the attention it would in the years to come, but his paintings would soon be celebrated posthumously.


Van Gogh's works, characterized by bold colors, dramatic brush strokes, and emotional honesty, have inspired generations of artists and captivated the public imagination. Today, he is remembered as a visionary whose art continues to move and challenge viewers around the world.

Vincent Willem van Gogh (30 March 1853 – 29 July 1890) was a post-impressionist painter whose profound influence on the art world has endured for over a century. Born in Groot-Zundert, Netherlands, on March 30, 1853, van Gogh initially pursued a career in theology before transitioning to art in his late twenties.

From a young age, van Gogh was fascinated by art, but his career took an artistic turn in 1880 when he settled in Paris to study art. There, he developed a love for Japanese prints and the works of Edgar Degas and Édouard Manet. However, despite his passion for art, van Gogh struggled with mental illness throughout his life and worked in relative obscurity, except for a few friends and family members.

His time in these areas was particularly productive, as he began creating some of his most iconic works, such as "Starry Night," "Sunflowers," and "The Bedroom." His signature style, characterized by bold brushstrokes and vivid colors, became synonymous with post-impressionism, even though he remained largely unappreciated during his lifetime.

Tragically, van Gogh's mental health issues reached a critical point in July 1890, and he took his own life by shooting himself in the chest. His death at the age of 37 marked the end of a turbulent yet influential life. However, the remarkable body of work he left behind continues to inspire artists and captivate audiences worldwide, cementing his place as one of the most celebrated artists in history.

He lived and worked in poverty, with brief periods of support from his sister, Wilhelmina, and artist friend, Paul Gauguin. Tragically, on July 29, 1890, at the age of 37, Van Gogh took his own life in Auvers-sur-Oise, France.

Today, Vincent van Gogh is celebrated as one of the most influential figures in Western art, and his iconic works continue to inspire, captivate, and move people across the world. Early Life:
Vincent van Gogh was born into a middle-class family of Dutch Reformed pastors. The youngest of eight children, Vincent struggled to connect with his family, particularly his strict father, who expected his children to follow his calling. Van Gogh had a close relationship with his mother and brother Theo, and Theo's unwavering support of Vincent's career greatly impacted him throughout his life.

Early Career:
Van Gogh started working as an art dealer and illustrator, but his passion for art soon drove him towards becoming a full-time painter. He moved to the countryside, where he studied the works of Dutch masters such as Rembrandt and Vermeer, as well as Japanese prints, and experimented with various artistic styles.

Later Years and Career:
In 1886, van Gogh moved to Paris, where he was exposed to the works of the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist movements. Inspired by artists like Camille Pissarro and Paul Gauguin, van Gogh developed his signature style characterized by bold colors, thick brushstrokes, and emotional intensity.

His most productive years were spent in Arles, in the South of France, where he created some of his most famous works, including "The Starry Night," "Sunflowers," and the iconic self-portrait. Van Gogh's unique artistic vision, however, was not understood or appreciated by many during his lifetime. He faced multiple rejections, financial struggles, and personal challenges, leading to depression and erratic behavior.

text:
Hey, this vibrant little storylet is all about Vincent van Gogh, that Dutch maestro whose paintings are like a rollercoaster for your eyes. Born in 1853 in a quaint Dutch town, Gogh grew up in a family who sold textiles, but oh boy, he wasn't made for that trade! Art was his calling, and it began as a teenage dream.

You see, Van Gogh was quite the character - a dreamer, a rebel, and an artist with emotions that ran deep. At 27, he dove headfirst into the art scene, selling his first painting, "The Potato Eaters," for a measly 300 florins (that's Dutch money back then). Not bad for a starving artist, right? But fame, sweet fame, wasn't really his cup of tea.

His journey took him across the globe, from the windy streets of Paris to the sun-soaked sands of Arles. His bold, swirling brushstrokes soon captured hearts and attention. Imagine a man with a swaggering beard, wild hair, and a palette full of vibrant hues! It's as if he poured his soul onto the canvas.

Though life was turbulent and mental health was his constant companion, Van Gogh churned out masterpieces like "The Starry Night," "Sunflowers," and "Irises." Each a testimony to his fierce love for life and colors.

Tragically, our hero spent his last days in a small room in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, painting with renewed vigor. He was a bit like a melancholic musician finding solace in his music. Alas, at the tender age of 37, he took his own life.

Today, Vincent van Gogh is celebrated as one of the greatest and most influential figures in the history of Western art. His name may have only gained fame posthumously, but his heartbreaking passion for art remains etched in every brushstroke. He was a man who dared to dream, dared to paint, and in doing so, gifted us with a legacy that still paints the world in vivid hues.

From a young age, van Gogh was immersed in art, but initially, he pursued a career in the ministry. In 1879, however, his life took a dramatic turn as he left his family and church to work as an art dealer in The Hague. It was during this time that he developed a deep appreciation for the simplicity and earnestness of peasant life and the natural world.

In 1881, Vincent relocated to Paris where he discovered the works of Impressionists and Post-Impressionists like Edgar Degas, Paul Gauguin, and Édouard Manet. This encounter with new artistic styles and ideas marked the beginning of a transformative phase in his life. He moved away from religious subjects and focused on the exploration of color, texture, and brushstrokes.

Van Gogh's move to the South of France in 1888 was a turning point in his life and work. In Arles, he found inspiration in the vibrant colors of the Provençal landscape, sunflowers, and the everyday scenes of his life and surroundings. This period produced many of his most famous works, including "Starry Night," "Sunflowers," and "The Bedroom."

Despite the enormous success of his art, Vincent van Gogh struggled with mental illness throughout his life. His dedication to his work often left him feeling isolated and misunderstood. Tragically, his mental health deteriorated, and on July 29, 1890, he took his own life at the age of 37.

Van Gogh's artistic legacy, however, was far from over. Today, he is celebrated as one of the most influential figures in the history of Western art. Despite his undeniable talent, van Gogh struggled to sell his paintings, leading to periods of financial hardship. He lived in various artists' colonies, seeking creative support and inspiration.

In a small Dutch village, under the golden hues of a pastoral sun, Vincent van Gogh took his first breath in 1853. The son of a minister, he was destined to tread the path of introspection and artistry. As a boy, his restless spirit yearned for a world beyond the church pews and family expectations, finding solace instead in the pages of letters and books.

Young Vincent's journey as an artist began humbly, as he traded the pastoral landscape for the coal mines and the harsh toil of a laborer, hoping to forge a life grounded in the hard work that his family upheld. But the soot-stained fingers and calloused hands would not define his destiny.

In 1880, with fervent conviction, Vincent embraced the world of art, traveling to Brussels and Paris, where his soul was ignited by the fire of innovation and the allure of colors. His early works, characterized by thick impasto and somber tones, bore the weight of his emotional turmoil, a testament to his unyielding passion for expressing the profound depths of his own experiences.

1886 marked a turning point in Vincent's life as he relocated to the vibrant city of Arles, hoping to establish a thriving artistic community. Here, his brilliance shone through, but so did his inner demons, as turbulent relationships and mental struggles began to gnaw at his mind.
